headline: Russia Sanctions Breakthrough
summary: The GOP restrains Trump, unlike Democrats on Obama and Iran.

headline: Wells Fargo to Refund $80 Million to Auto-Loan Customers
summary: Wells Fargo said it plans to make refunds to certain auto-loan customers who may have been improperly charged for some auto insurance.

headline: Coinbase Is Nearing Close on $100 Million in Funding
summary: Coinbase exchanges cryptocurrencies bitcoin, ethereum and litecoin, and offers a bitcoin payment-processing platform for merchants.

headline: Toshiba Agrees to Provide Notice to Western Digital in Chip-Unit Sale
summary: Toshiba and Western Digital reached a partial truce in their dispute over their memory-chip joint venture in Japan, with Toshiba agreeing to provide notice before it concludes any deal to sell its interest in the venture.

headline: One Dead in Hamburg Stabbing Attack
summary: A man from the United Arab Emirates who had sought asylum in Germany killed one person and injured six others in a stabbing rampage at a Hamburg supermarket, officials said.

headline: CBS Adds Redstone’s Lawyer to Board of Directors
summary: CBS Corp. has added the attorney of former chairman Sumner Redstone to its board of directors.

headline: The Agony of Venezuela
summary: Nicolás Maduro’s bid for an electoral coup is leading to civil war.

headline: Wisconsin Governor Calls Special Session for Foxconn Incentive Package
summary: Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker on Friday called a special legislative session next week focused on a multibillion-dollar incentive package for an industrial facility announced this week by Foxconn Technology Group.

headline: The Republican ObamaCare Crack Up
summary: The party had a historic chance to act in the public interest. It failed.

headline: Where There’s Smoke There’s Fire for Tobacco Stocks
summary: Curbs on nicotine could be disastrous for tobacco stocks such as Altria, and the dip after the news doesn’t make the stocks cheap enough to represent a buying opportunity.

headline: Kelly Met President Trump Through Priebus
summary: The White House’s new chief of staff, John Kelly, had never met Mr. Trump before he was offered the job of Homeland Security secretary—by the man he is now going to replace.

headline: Indian Health Service to End Some Care at South Dakota Hospital
summary: The Indian Health Service said Friday that it would permanently close critical medical services at a troubled hospital it operates in South Dakota a year after federal regulators found poor care at the facility.

headline: Compromise VA Funding Measure Passes House
summary: The House of Representatives unanimously approved a measure considered crucial for funding health care for many American veterans; the bill is likely to be approved by the Senate and sent to the White House to be signed into law, proponents said.

headline: Dollar Falls After U.S. Growth Data
summary: The dollar’s slide intensified Friday after data showed U.S. inflation remains tepid despite a pickup in economic growth.

headline: Mnuchin Says It Is ‘Critical’ Congress Raise the Debt Limit By Sept. 29
summary: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin urged Congress to raise the federal borrowing limit by Sept. 29, and said he would continue to suspend the issuance of new Treasury debt through that date.

headline: Agency Says Border Wall Prototypes Could Move Ahead if Deemed Urgent
summary: The Department of Homeland Security cited processes at the Government Accountability Office for a delay in building prototypes for the promised southwest border wall. But the GAO responded the agency could go ahead if the project were deemed urgent.

headline: Charlie Gard, Terminally Ill Child at Center of U.K. Court Debate, Dies
summary: The British infant at the center of a thorny international debate about who has the power to decide the fate of a terminally ill child, died Friday, one week before his first birthday.

headline: U.S. Sanctions Six Entities Related to Iran Missile Program
summary: The U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned six Iran-based entities that officials said are central to Tehran’s ballistic-missile program, a move coming one day after the country tested a rocket designed to carry a satellite.

headline: Arrange Flowers Like a Pro—Starting With an Unlikely Inspiration
summary: Floral designer Lindsey Taylor captures the tranquility—and simmering unease—in a painting by early-20th-century expressionist Richard Gerstl, known as ‘Austria’s van Gogh’.

headline: Trump: Police Shouldn’t Be ’Too Nice’ to ’Thugs’ Under Arrest
summary: President Donald Trump told a crowd of law-enforcement officers they shouldn’t be “too nice” when arresting “thugs,” in remarks about combating gang activity.

headline: Photos of the Day: July 28
summary: In photos selected Friday by Wall Street Journal editors, Pakistan’s prime minister is removed from office, Palestinians pray outside one of Jerusalem’s holiest sites, protesters await Donald Trump’s arrival in Long Island, and more.

headline: Treasury Yields Edge Lower
summary: U.S. government-bond prices rose Friday after data showed U.S. economic growth picked up in the second quarter, but that inflation remained tepid.

headline: Trump Eyes Columbia Professor for SEC Seat
summary: The White House is preparing to nominate Columbia University law professor Robert Jackson to a Democratic slot on the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Chipotle Seeks a ‘Kill Step’
summary: America’s growing taste for fresh greens is a challenge to food-handling practices.

headline: In Praise of the Regional Museum
summary: At the Witte Museum you can see a state flag carried on a moon walk, models of circus wagons, an enormous stuffed feral hog and more, objects that reflect the area’s distinctive experience and perspective.

headline: Uber Approaches GE CEO Jeff Immelt About Top Role
summary: Uber Technologies is considering General Electric CEO Jeff Immelt among a handful of candidates for its top position.

headline: Metals: Gold Climbs to Six-Week High
summary: Gold prices rose for the second day in a row Friday, on slower-than-expected U.S. economic growth and increased worries over political risks.

headline: Five Best: Peter Stansky
summary: The author of “Edward Upward: Art and Life” on violence and visionaries.

headline: The Best New Children’s Books
summary: Meghan Cox Gurdon on a graphic-novel adaptation of Poe and other books for young readers.

headline: Maybe Cities Were a Bad Idea
summary: Hunter-gatherers were healthier than humans who settled in early cities. They were less violent too. Felipe Fernández-Armesto reviews “Built on Bones” by Brenna Hassett.

headline: Lizzie Borden Revisited
summary: Sarah Schmidt’s new novel explores the famous case of the well-brought-up girl who killed (or maybe didn’t) her father and stepmother. Allan Massie reviews “See What I Have Done.”

headline: Election Officials, Homeland Security Begin to Formalize Cybersecurity Efforts
summary: Officials from a dozen states and the federal government took preliminary steps this week toward more formal cooperation regarding election-security efforts at a two-day meeting in New York.

headline: Raging Against the Machine
summary: The labor disaster that inspired classic protest songs by Woody Guthrie and Bob Dylan. Randall Fuller reviews “Grown-Up Anger” by Daniel Wolff.

headline: Randles’s Take: Fyre Festival Lender Talks of Quick Bankruptcy That Wasn’t
summary: Lender EHL Funding says it was led to believe that the company behind the doomed music festival would file for bankruptcy soon after the festival’s collapse. The specter of bankruptcy influenced how EHL sought to recoup its loan.

headline: What’s Next on Ron Shaich’s Menu
summary: After a $7.5 billion sale, the CEO of Panera and ‘fast-casual’ dining pioneer sees other needs to feed

headline: U.S. Oil Rig Count Rises by Two
summary: The number of rigs drilling for oil in the U.S. rose by two in the past week to 766, according to oil-field services company Baker Hughes, now a unit of General Electric Co.

headline: EPA Fund Recipients Side With the Agency
summary: What we see at the EPA is the flip side of regulatory capture.

headline: ‘Dunkirk’: On Point or Missing the Point?
summary: For all its restraint, it is still a powerful experience to watch.

headline: Over to You, Tom
summary: ObamaCare gave enormous discretion to regulators. Now Team Trump must use it to help insurance consumers.

headline: Merck Says Cyberattack Hit Production, Will Hurt Profit
summary: Merck said its second-quarter earnings rose as the drugmaker recorded blockbuster growth for its cancer drug Keytruda.

headline: Justice Kennedy’s Smooth Talk Didn’t Persuade Scalia
summary: Scalia once said ‘I would hide my head in a bag’ if he had to join an opinion that began as Justice Kennedy’s did ingay-marriage case.

headline: Colin Kaepernick Is NFL’s Biggest Offseason Puzzle
summary: The polarizing quarterback, who created a firestorm with his national-anthem protests last year, still hasn’t been signed despite playing decent as a starter last year

headline: Great Lighthouses of America
summary: A new book celebrates some of America’s greatest lighthouses. Here are some vivid examples.

headline: The Best Bluetooth Headphones for People Who Lose Stuff
summary: They may look bulky, but neckband earbuds are surprisingly comfortable and won’t tie you up in knots. A review of the BeatsX, Klipsch X12, Sennheiser HD1 In-Ear Wireless and V-Moda Forza Metallo Wireless.

headline: Investors Too Wary of the Amazon Effect
summary: Companies’ stocks fall when Amazon enters their business, but the reaction is often overblown. That creates an opportunity for investors.

headline: Republicans Search for Answers; Can They Find Any Across the Aisle?
summary: In the wake of the health-bill collapse, Republicans are left with no obvious path forward. Except perhaps, Gerald F. Seib writes, to try to find a way to work with Democrats.

headline: Laurene Powell Jobs Buys Majority Stake in the Atlantic
summary: Laurene Powell Jobs’s philanthropic organization, the Emerson Collective, is purchasing an undisclosed stake in the Atlantic magazine and its website from David Bradley.

headline: The Shark’s Pretty Teeth
summary: How Louis Armstrong turned a song about the vicious exploits of a murderer in 18th-century London into a jazz hit.

headline: Fiat Chrysler Gets Approval to Sell Diesel Vehicles Amid Ongoing Emissions Probe
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles received approval from government regulators to sell 2017 model year vehicles equipped with diesel engines after a months-long delay and amid a probe into the company’s alleged use of illegal emissions software.

headline: Will We Soon See Singing, Acting Politicians?
summary: As entertainers ponder political careers, Joe Queenan wonders whether politicians will fight back in TV, movies and music.

headline: Making Last-Minute Travel Plans for the Solar Eclipse? Read This First
summary: Expert stargazers offer travel tips on how best to see next month’s solar eclipse.

headline: American Cycling’s New Oath
summary: Oath CEO Tim Armstrong on why his company joined up with American cycling outfit Cannondale-Drapac.

headline: U.S. Consumer Sentiment Fell in July
summary: Consumer confidence in the economy is at a 12-year high, but optimism about the future is deteriorating

headline: Jake Butcher’s Triumph With 1982 World’s Fair Swiftly Turned Sour
summary: The 1982 World’s Fair seemed to be Jake Butcher’s moment of triumph. The day after the fair closed, federal regulators raided many of the banks controlled by Mr. Butcher and his brother, leading to the collapse of their banking empire. Mr. Butcher died July 19 at 81.

headline: ‘Bo’ Pilgrim Made a Fortune From Chicken Feed and Credited God for His Progress
summary: Lonnie “Bo” Pilgrim was the co-founder of Pilgrim’s Pride, one of the world’s largest processors of chicken. The self-made entrepreneur, who insisted that his success was entirely due to God’s guidance, died July 21 at 89.

headline: How Dutch-Based ‘Beleaguered’ Ended Up in a Trump Tweet
summary: Ben Zimmer on how ‘beleaguered,’ a word with Dutch roots, ended up in a Trump tweet about Jeff Sessions

headline: Meet the Descendants of a German Massacre in Africa a Century Ago
summary: A 1904 uprising in what is now called Namibia turned into a war of annihilation waged by German troops against the Herero and Nama peoples.

headline: Sears Canada’s Largest Stockholders Call Off Joint Bankruptcy Bid
summary: Two hedge-fund managers called off a potential joint bankruptcy deal for Sears Canada, clearing the way for other bidders to challenge the two largest shareholders.

headline: Chevron Swings to Profit, Buoyed by Cost Cuts
summary: Chevron swung to a profit in the second quarter as it benefited from higher crude oil and natural gas prices and efforts to cut costs throughout its operations.

headline: Canada GDP Roars in May
summary: The Canadian economy grew at a surprisingly robust pace in May, led by energy and manufacturing, a result sure to reinforce market expectations of another rate rise this year.

headline: UBS, Credit Suisse Boost Earnings After Strategic Shift
summary: UBS and Credit Suisse posted better-than-expected quarterly profit, suggesting their bets on managing money for well-heeled clients have paid off.

headline: Minnesota Firm Hopes to Make a Big Splash—With Shrimp
summary: Ralco, a technology-focused animal-nutrition company, is planning a nine-acre indoor bayou in Minnesota that will pump out more than 8 million pounds of farm-raised shrimp annually.

headline: U.S. Employment Costs Decelerated in Second Quarter
summary: A broad gauge of U.S. wages and benefits advanced only modestly this spring, the latest sign of little pressure on labor costs despite what appears to be a tight labor market.

headline: Sapphire Reserve Cards Not So Rewarding for J.P. Morgan
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase & Co.’s Sapphire Reserve premium credit card, launched one year ago, is raising concerns within the bank that it won’t make money because of high demand and generous rewards.

headline: The 10-Point: Gerard Baker on the Failed ‘Skinny’ Obamacare Repeal, Strong Corporate Earnings, Semiconductor Nationalism and More
summary: A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.

headline: Torry’s Take: For Savers, Prioritizing a Smaller Balance Sheet Isn’t Water Under the Bridge
summary: Savers haven’t had a good run of it in recent years. The eight years in which short-term interest rates languished at zero may be over for Americans, but returns on deposits are yet to eke out discernible gains.

headline: Saudi Coalition Says Intercepted Missile Fired at Mecca by Houthi Rebels
summary: A Saudi Arabia-led military coalition said it shot down a ballistic missile fired at Saudi territory by Houthi rebels in Yemen.

headline: Why Pandas Are Becoming Popular in Hungary
summary: The Hungarian government raised $148 million this week by selling ‘panda bonds’—yuan-denominated debt issued by foreign governments or companies in China—and other countries are preparing to do likewise.

headline: Santander Upbeat on Banco Popular Buy as Profit Rises
summary: Santander reported a rise in second-quarter profit and said its recent acquisition of Banco Popular Español would boost returns as Spain’s economic recovery accelerates.

headline: Bad News If You Make $150,000 to $300,000: Higher Taxes for Many
summary: If President Donald Trump sticks to what he has said, Americans earning between $149,400 and $307,900 are most likely to see an increase in their taxes as a result of tax reform.

headline: Barclays Pushed to Loss by Africa Write-Down
summary: Barclays swung to a second-quarter net loss as it took a hit on the disposal of its Africa operations and higher provisions for conduct costs.

headline: Rising Ticket Prices Help British Airways Parent Fly High
summary: British Airways parent IAG said second-quarter net profit surged 20%, with the carrier benefiting from rising ticket prices, in common with its European and U.S. rivals.

headline: Baidu’s Search for Better Revenue Growth Continues
summary: China’s search giant has had a better year so far than 2016, but it still lags behind rivals Tencent and Alibaba.

headline: UBS Profit Beats Expectations
summary: UBS said its quarterly net profit rose 14%, as revenues slightly exceeded analysts’ expectations and the Swiss banking giant saw healthy inflows into its wealth-management division.

headline: Baidu Profit Rises in Rebound From Beijing Crackdown
summary: Chinese search giant Baidu has bounced back from a medical scandal that dragged down earnings, posting its first profit increase in three quarters.

headline: Toshiba Bankruptcy a Nice Idea, But Hard to Execute
summary: The nuclear option of bankruptcy could give Toshiba a fresh start. It’s a nice idea, but the embattled Japanese giant is more likely to choose to muddle through.

headline: Trump to Sign Russia Sanctions Bill
summary: White House officials previously wouldn’t commit to whether President Donald Trump would sign the bill, saying a provision that requires the executive branch to consult Congress before relaxing any sanctions against Russia may infringe on presidential authority.

headline: Russia to Kick Out Some U.S. Diplomats Over Sanctions
summary: Russia struck out at the U.S., forcing Washington to cut its diplomatic presence in the country and closing a U.S. diplomatic retreat outside Moscow after Congress passed a new round of sanctions against Russia.

headline: Meet Randal Quarles, Trump’s Pick to Shake Up the Fed
summary: Randal Quarles became skeptical of government intervention during decades of work in the financial world. Now he is set to take the lead in shaping oversight at one of the greatest interveners of all: the Federal Reserve.

headline: Sprint Proposes Merger With Charter Communications
summary: Sprint Chairman Masayoshi Son is pursuing a full-blown merger of the wireless carrier with Charter that would create a media and communications giant.

headline: Health Bill’s Defeat Roils Republicans, Insurers
summary: The abrupt collapse of Republicans’ bid to rework the U.S. health-care system opened a new chapter of uncertainty for insurers, medical providers and millions of Americans, as officials weighed divergent options for the road ahead.

headline: The Three GOP Senators Who Ended the Health-Care Repeal
summary: Republican Sens. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, Susan Collins of Maine and John McCain of Arizona tapped into their strong political brands in their home states when they joined Democratic senators in blocking a slimmed-down Affordable Care Act repeal measure.

headline: FDA Wants Nicotine in Cigarettes to Be Cut to Nonaddictive Levels
summary: U.S. health officials said they want tobacco companies to make all cigarettes with such low levels of nicotine that they are no longer addictive, part of a regulatory overhaul that threatens Big Tobacco’s main moneymaker.

headline: U.S. Economy Glides Back to Steady, Modest Growth Path
summary: The U.S. entered the ninth year of economic expansion in steady but unspectacular fashion that shows little sign of abating.

headline: ‘God’s ACLU’ Seeks Freedom for the Faithful
summary: The Becket Fund’s head on why religious liberty extends beyond church—and why the ‘Slants’ case helps believers.

headline: Uber’s CEO Search Reaches New Degree of Difficulty
summary: A multibillion-dollar investment offer by SoftBank is further complicating recruitment efforts at Uber that are already bogged down by legal challenges, a lack of direction and divisions over what the company needs in a leader.

headline: Athens Today and Yesterday
summary: Ancient Athens persuaded the world that it was exceptional. No wonder modern Greeks can’t live up to the standard.

headline: John Quincy Adams on Paper
summary: The candid diary of a great American statesman is a matchless window on the early republic. Richard Brookhiser reviews “The Diaries of John Quincy Adams,” edited by David Waldstreicher.

headline: Housman’s World in Miniature
summary: A.E. Housman’s poetry distilled the experience of English youth in the early 20th century. Jamie James reviews “Housman Country” by Peter Parker.

headline: America Has a Bacon Problem: Our Pigs Aren’t Fat Enough
summary: A hankering for lardier pork chops and greasier sausages has butchers scrambling to acquire the porky breeds of yore.

headline: The Meditation Cure: When the Buddha Meets Darwin
summary: A basic practice of Buddhism turns out to be one of the best ways to deal with the anxieties and appetites bequeathed to us by our evolutionary history.

headline: Germany Confronts the Forgotten Story of Its Other Genocide
summary: A war in Namibia, considered the first mass ethnic killing of the 20th century, is today at the center of negotiations over an apology and compensation. If the countries can successfully conclude talks, the outcome may be a model for other post-colonial powers grappling with past atrocities.

headline: French Economy’s Growth in Second Quarter Boosts Macron After Setbacks
summary: The French economy maintained firm growth in the second quarter, giving President Emmanuel Macron a shot in the arm as he embarks upon contentious plans to rewrite labor laws and cut public spending.

headline: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ
summary: Delivering up-to-the minute news, analysis, interviews and explanatory journalism on logistics, supply-chain management, e-commerce and more

headline: Rooster Teeth Fans Flock to Live Events
summary: Once sequestered to YouTube and other web spaces, niche online entertainers such as Rooster Teeth are getting into the convention trade as they seek new sources of revenue to grow their franchises.
